content.description: Two cruxes with quality but easier climbing in between. The guide mentions only one short stuff crux, but I found there to be two hard sections leading me to believe a hold may have broken on this. Follow a sharp crimpy face on black streaks to a roof, pull the roof to a rest and a deceptive and crimpy crux to the last bolt. One last lock off leads to anchors. Needs new LOs.
content.protection: 8 bolts to anchors. Needs new LOs
content.location: In the black streaks in the middle of the big face. Pulls the big roof on the left side where there is a flake/corner.

content.description: Start just left of Lumiere and climb easy terrain to the second bolt. From here, encounter a very continuous section(depending if you move to the jug at the piton on Lumiere) with a hard boulder just above the forth bolt. Rest in the horizontal, then tackle back to back boulders to the anchors. An excellent route with great rock, only slightly marred by the rest shared with Lumiere.

Great route, it lies on the Sundog wall. It's the second route from the last on the right side. The crimpy crux is within the first two bolts. After that pull a small roof and sustained crimpy climbing follows to the anchors.
content.location: On Sundog wall at Fletchers bluff. On the right side of the wall.

content.description: Start below an overlap, climb up to an undercling and an impossibly long reach(height dependent). From here, head right then back left, pull a small roof and head straight up on big moves to the anchors.
content.protection: The route is well bolted. Though a few clips may be reachy for shorter climbers.  5 bolts plus a 0.5 cam
content.location: On the left side of the Sundog Wall but right of the big slab.

content.description: Follow bolts to a small roof and continue above the roof on small crimps (crux).
content.location: Located just to the right of Sunnyside Up.

content.description: Start on Meltdown, clipping the first two(second with 24” runner) then climb bolts three and four of Sunnyside Up, finally moving left along a horizontal crack into Sundog below its last bolt. A .5-.75 sized piece protects the runout from Sunnyside Up into Sundog. Best warm up or just a good route in general.
content.protection: Five bolts and a .5-.75 piece. One 24” runner on second bolt or back clean

climbs.name: Lumiere
climbs.fa: Paula King, Ward Smith, Chris Smith, Wayne Burleson, & Dave Jones, 1992

content.description: Follow three bolts to a fixed pin in a horizontal crack. Continue following bolts up and slightly left to the top.
content.location: Just to the right of White Heat.   You can recognize the route pretty easily from the accompanying photos.

content.description: Start in bushes below a beautiful water stained slab. Tricky climbing up the face leads to a roof feature. Climb past this to a pumpy traverse then a rest. Tricky and reachy moves lead to the chains.
content.protection: 9 bolts to lower offs. A few slings are helpful as the route wanders a bit.
content.location: Toward the left side of the Sundog Wall. This route is just right of Too Close for Comfort.

content.description: This is a link-up that provides the line of least resistance to the top of the Sundog Wall. Start on After the Gold Rush, go up and left to a ramp. Follow the ramp/ledge leftward, and eventually go straight up (crux) to finish on Bear Necessities.
content.protection: bolted. You might want to place something to supplement the bolts.
content.location: Start up some blocks that lead up and left to a ramp/ledge (see photo).

content.description: Follow a series of underclings, with each one becoming a little harder than the last until moving up a technical face. Cop a rest at a large hold then finish up another technical but easier face to lower offs.
content.location: Just left of Sundog, marked by the series of undercling flakes.

content.description: Fletchers Bluff is a large and complex cliff band in a quiet and remote setting. There are six sectors, Left End, Kansas Wall, Central Wall, Ollie’s area, Moondog wall, and the Sundog Wall. As of now, there are only some of the Sundog routes listed. The cliff has many styles of climbing, from slabs, to roofs, to cracks of all sizes and most notably, excellent face climbing. The cliff is south facing and generally very warm, a good winter destination if you can get out there(road is not maintained for winter travel). Some areas seep, especially the Sundog area, where most routes will be wet in the spring, and seeps will return after heavy rain. The rock at Fletchers is excellent, and hopefully more climbers will get out here in the future. This is one of those places that doesn’t see the traffic it deserves.
